frameset.note: Frames file for 'take' based on survey of sentences from big corpus

role.descr: entity taken from, or prepositional complement of arg1

example.name: take office
example.text: President Carlos Menem took office July 8.

example.name: extract
example.text: Sony took a lesson from the American management books.

example.name: view
example.text: Principals take cheating seriously

example.name: take the law
example.text: She took the law into her own hands

example.name: take measures
example.text: It has taken measures to prevent cheating.

example.name: take advantage
example.text: According to industry lawyers, the ruling gives pipeline companies an important second chance *trace* to resolve remaining disputes and take advantage of the cost-sharing mechanism.

example.name: take some comfort
example.text: Investors unsetled by the stock market's recent gyrations can take some comfort in the predictable arrival of quarterly dividend checks.
example.arg: Investors unsettled by the stock market's recent gyrations
the predictable arrival of quarterly dividend checks

example.name: takin' care of business
example.text: Frank plans the program, takes care of business, and approaches the work like any other job.

example.name: put up or shut up
example.text: John couldn't take his medicine like a man.

example.name: tough movement
example.text: That got hard *trace* to take.
example.note: Trace might or might not be there, or there might be a trace in the object position pointing to the 'that'. The underlying sentence is "for (someone) to take that, is hard."

example.name: resultative
example.text: John took his company private.

example.name: bummer
example.text: They took the announcement as bad news.

example.name: it support, kinda
example.text: I take it, then, that John is a complete and utter idiot?
example.arg: John is a complete and utter idiot
example.note: Again, this is a 'dummy' it, without any real semantic substance.

example.name: take place
example.text: These events took place 35 years ago.

example.name: made up, but based on real
example.text: John's company took a $5 million write-off due to unwise investments in jellybeans.
example.arg: due to unwise investments in jellybeans

example.name: active
example.text: Being so fragile and minute, they will take special special robotic handling equipment.

example.name: it-support
example.text: It [*EXP*-1] took me a half-hour [*] to move 10 feet from my parking spot in an outer lot to an aisle, and an additional hour to reach an inner roadway a half-block away.
example.arg: [*] to move 10 feet from my parking spot in an outer lot to an aisle
example.note: Be careful that you don't give an argument number to 'dummy' it

example.name: typical out-of-order
example.text: Graduate students are taking longer than ever [*-1] to get their doctor of philosophy degrees, the National Research Council says.
example.arg: [*-1] to get their doctor of philosophy degrees

example.name: surprise!
example.text: Rumors of an impending devaluation have been circulating in Moscow for weeks , but the size of the cut took many Western bankers by surprise .

example.name: ballooning? really?
example.text: Americans it seems [0] [*T*-1] have followed Malcolm Forbes 's hot-air lead and taken to ballooning in a heady way .

example.name: Calgon, take me away!
example.text: Marshall Coleman wants to *trace* take away your right to choose

example.name: Arg0 rel Arg1
example.text: This exclusive club has taken in a host of flashy new members
example.arg: a host of flashy new members

example.name: take it all off
example.text: John took off all his clothes in public.

example.name: zoom
example.text: The pace has taken off.

example.name: leavin' on a jet plane...
example.text: Keep in mind that this is the same movie in which a character is flattened by a steamroller only to pop right back up and peer in the window of a Boeing 747 -- from the outside -- as it takes off.

example.name: mental health day
example.text: And when Mr. Engelken asked him why he took time [*ICH*-1] [*ICH*-2] off from work for somebody he didn't even know [*T*-4] [*T*-5] [*T*-6]...
example.arg: for someone he didn't even know
example.note: Nasty bit of syntax by the treebankers, there.

roleset.name: take on: acquire

example.name: simple transitive
example.text: A young, short-term employee can't take on any responsibility

roleset.note: refer to acquire and other verbs-of-acquisition for usage of higher-numbered args

example.name: David and Goliath
example.text: ``I will sit down and talk some of the problems out, but take on the political system? Uh-uh,'' he says with a shake of the head.

example.name: take out an ad
example.text: A company once took out an ad.

example.name: unstated object
example.text: Mrs. Ward took over in 1986

example.name: with object
example.text: John took over the company.

example.name: with attribute
example.text: John took over as president

example.name: vaguely passive
example.text: Most of the picture is taken up with endless scenes of talking heads.
example.arg: with endless scenes of talking heads

example.name: active
example.text: The Senate will take up the measure quickly.

example.name: with arg2
example.text: They took it up with Warner.

roleset.name: take aback: different kind of surprise

example.name: only passive
example.text: He is taken [*-4] aback in an interview when asked whether, as mayor, he plans on reforming the political ``fiefdoms'' that perpetuate the monumental ineffectiveness of New York's school system.
example.arg: when asked whether, as mayor, he plans on reforming the political ``fiefdoms'' that perpetuate the monumental ineffectiveness of New York's school system
